Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2017 01:35AM - edited Jul 9, 2017 01:36AM by mazie73 I've had the same pain for months, though it's about 2 inches above my hairline on the right side, near where I part my hair. I did have a skull met closer to the back of my head, but it's disappeared with treatment (clinical trial of Abemaciclib + pi3k inhibitor + faslodex). I haven't brought up the pain to my MO, but scans haven't shown any new skull mets. Honestly, I've attributed the pain to the fact that I spend a lot of time hunched over a computer and it's probably nerve pain.
Posts.Title: Pain on head worried about possible skull mets curleygirly curleygirly

Posts.Content: mazie73 wrote: Hi all, I'm currently on a clinical trial, taking Abemaciclib, Faslodex and a Pi3k inhibitor. Three scans showed consistent improvement — the clinical trial folks measured a 56 percent reduction in tumor size. But, the last scan showed stable disease. My oncologist was happy with those results, as was my clinical trial coordinator. But, I'm not happy. I'm worried that this is evidence the medication has stopped working and we'll see disease progression on the next scan. My oncologist explained that this likely isn't the case, and that she has patients whose results will show stable disease for years. I'm still freaking out. Any advice? I'm seeing a therapist at my cancer center, and I have an appointment tomorrow. I'm sure she'll tell me that this is another example of my tendency toward catastrophic thinking. ​Currently on a clinical trial at UC San Diego Moores Cancer Center: Abemaciclib + Pi3 kinase inhibitor + Faslodex Dx 8/2013, IDC, Right, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 9/23/2013 Lymph node removal: Sentinel; Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Chemotherapy 1/28/2014 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 5/15/2014 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Hormonal Therapy 5/21/2014 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Dx 12/2016, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/lungs, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 2/4/2017 Faslodex (fulvestrant), Zoladex (goserelin) Targeted Therapy Verzenio Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stable disease = unstable mind mazie73 Cure-ious

Posts.Title: How Many Are We? zarovka SimonH

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2015 11:15PM mazie73 wrote: Hi all— I'm weighing in a little late here. I found out I was allergic to Codeine after a tonsillectomy when I was 19 (that *was not* pretty). I was prescribed Vicodin after my mastectomy and I was a little wary, since Vicodin and Codeine are both opioids. Not only did Vicodin do nothing for the pain; it made me feel nauseous. Fortunately, Tylenol was all I needed (thanks to recommendations from ladies on this discussion group). I brought up my problem with Vicodin when I had my reconstruction and got a prescription for Percocet. It's what they prescribe folks who are allergic to Codeine, because it's a synthetic opioid. It worked beautifully—and I only had to take it for four days. Best of luck to y'all.
Posts.Title: Pain Meds make me vomit! What do I do? MizMimi JanS1234567890

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2014 11:48PM mazie73 wrote: Hi Nikkito:  I was diagnosed in early August 2013 and just finished chemo last week. If you get bad news (hoping you won't), I think you'll be amazed by how you're able to get through it all. I was reading an article recently, written by a doctor who was diagnosed with cancer. He quoted a line from a Samuel Beckett play that had become his mantra: "I can't go on. I'll go on." I've kind of adopted that, too. One foot in front of the other. I just finished chemo last week. Would I have rather not gone through any of this? Of course. But I've learned so much along the way.  Here's a great blog on breast cancer by a young woman from Toronto: http://passmeanothercupcake.com
Posts.Title: Where I'm at...just needing a little support Nikkito Ddkath70

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2017 12:14AM - edited Jun 1, 2017 12:15AM by mazie73 I'm taking Abemaciclib, too. Also, Faslodex and a Pik3 inhibitor (no name yet, but it's by Eli Lilly). This is for a clinical trial at Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego. I've been on this combo since the beginning of February and so far, so good. Diarrhea is the only significant side effect, and some tiredness every now and then. Unlike Ibrance, there's no off week. Moderators: can you add Abemaciclib to the list of targeted therapies
